photos.description: Logs being dumped from the bluff at the far south end of the beach - just past the waterfall.  The logs came from various property owned by Carroll including the "bluff "property and the "40".  I believe the logger was a fellow named McIntyre who "selectively " logged leaving primarily second growth trees.
photos.notes: Part of a "Flip-Pak" booklet that includes images 0131-0139

photos.description: Logs spilling over the bluff at the end of the beach. The logs came from various property owned by Carroll including the "bluff "property and the "40".  I believe the logger was a fellow named McIntyre. (Ken)
photos.notes: Part of a "Flip-Pak" booklet that includes images 0131-0139

photos.description: Loggers booming up logs to be towed to a mainland mill. The logs came from various property owned by Carroll including the "bluff "property and the "40".  Many of these were old growth Douglas Fir - magnificent old trees that loggers coveted.  The thinking of the time was that the old trees should be thinned out to make room for new second growth trees to flourish.   (Ken)
photos.notes: Part of a "Flip-Pak" booklet that includes images 0131-0139

photos.description: Snow covering the overhead ramp which led to the office, store, and front porch of the lodge.  The Bronze light on the pole is a ships lantern that Carroll obtained in his merchant marine travels.  It currently resides in Ken Culver's family cabin at Orcas.  (Ken)
photos.notes: Part of a "Flip-Pak" booklet that includes images 0131-0139

photos.description: Snapshot showing the floats and rental boats.  Note some boats were pulled up on the large float when not in use, but they had to be constantly splashed with salt water inside to keep the seams from opening up and leaking like a sieve.  The box like affair on the left of the large float was a fish cleaning station.  Immediately to its right was a trap door in the float that lifted up to reveal a herring live box with herring swimming around and cod fish and the occasional dogfish lurking wantingly on the other side of the screen.  We used a dip net to get out as many as the fisherman wanted to buy.  $1 per dozen was the going rate for live herring.   (Ken)
Bruce, Ken, and Carolyn in front of the "oil room" on the boathouse platform.   (Ken)
photos.notes: Part of a "Flip-Pak" booklet that includes images 0131-0139

photos.people: Bruce Culver, Ken Culver, Carolyn Culver
photos.description: Ken and Bruce in front of the oil room.  Carolyn was there, but this was the early days of film photography and it must have been the end of the roll.  (Ken)
photos.notes: Part of a "Flip-Pak" booklet that includes images 0131-0139

photos.description: Hand tinted photo of Alderbrook Farm during spring bloom. Cherries, apples, Italian plumb prunes, and a few pears. The San Juans were the providers of much fresh fruit until the Irrigation Projects of Roosevelt's New Deal in Eastern Washington put them out of business.  (Ken)
Bruce, Ken, and Carolyn Culver at Grandma Rothenhoefer's home in Seattle. Ken is wearing his pledge pin from the Delta Tau Delta fraternity at the Universiy of Washington.  (Ken)
Bruce, Ken, and Carolyn Culver at Grandma Rothenhoefer's home in Seattle. Ken is wearing his pledge pin from the Delta Tau Delta fraternity at the Universiy of Washington.  (Ken)
On the front steps of the family home in the Phillipines where she lived with her family at a mining camp where her father Louis was a mining engineer.

photos.people: Ken Culver, Jean (Rothenhoefer) Culver, Bruce Culver, Carroll Culver
Ken Culver, Bruce Culver, Carolyn Culver at Pt. Lawrence
photos.description: My guess is we were all dressed up for Sunday School at the Episcopal Church in Eastsound.  My Mom drove us to and fro - but my Dad was not a church attender.  He always maintained that sitting alone on a hill above the Lodge was a close to God as he needed to get.

Ken's class photo - grades 5 and 6 which were combined in one class room. Teacher Mrs. Van Moorham.  Nellie S. Milton School Eastsound Washington. Ken Culver 3rd from left in back row. John Willis far left back row. Perry Kimple to Ken's left, and Jim Perry next to him. (Ken)

The infamous "closing day" parade at the Community Beach at Shoreacres -Doe Bay. Carroll and Judy in his beloved "shoe" boat, a converted seine skiff that could be parked on the beach at low tide, allowing them to go into shallow spots where other boats could not go, often at Sucia Island.  Carroll loved to dress up for things like this.(Ken)
